content: this one is dedicated to all you crafters doing it the hard way hey guys
welcome back to another episode of black magic crafts today I am going to
complete the last piece of my cavern set that I am going to be giving away to one
of my patreon supporters the last remaining piece is a couple bookcases
this is a really good project to build because bookcases can be utilized in all
sorts of different scenarios in a tabletop role-playing game you will get
a lot of mileage out of simple little bookcases I know what you're thinking
I'm probably gonna whip out the procs on and some jigs and some XPS insulation
foam and make up these little bookcases and you're sitting there going I don't
have a hot wire cutter I can't get this insulation foam and I definitely don't
have any jigs cuz I don't have a hot wire cutter this episode is for you
I'm gonna make these bookcases the exact same way that I made my set of bookcases
that I've been using in my game for like two years that I built before I owned a
hot wire table or any fancy tools I didn't let those restrictions get in
my way they used an Olfa knife and dollar-store foam core board that's it
well also some white glue everybody can get their hands on a utility knife of
some sort most people can get their hands on this Dollar Tree foam core not
everyone but you can find some sort of standing could I make these faster and
easier and possibly better-looking using the tools that I often do on this
channel yes it definitely could but today I want to prove a point that it
doesn't matter what you have you can still make cool detailed terrain pieces
for your game table so with all of that being said let's jump over to the table
and build some little miniature bookcases the very first thing you need
to do if you're gonna be using blades instead of a hot wire to complete a
project like this is put on some new sharp blades this foam core board comes
from the store with a weird serrated edge on it so the first thing you want
to do is cut off that edge so you have a nice clean starting line and then I'm
gonna rip a strip that is one in five eighths of an inch wide and this will
serve as the back of the bookcases you'll notice that even though I'm just
using thin foam core I'm still cutting with multiple passes this will ensure I
have a nice clean cut now for the actual shelves I'm cutting some strips that are
half an inch wide the width of the side pieces are determined by the depth of
the Shelf plus the thickness of the material used on the back when cutting
down the pieces to length for the back I first squared the corner using a metal
carpenter square I then cut down these pieces to two and three eighths of an
inch long and it's at this point that I pulled the paper off both sides of all
of my pieces to cut the shelves to length I just used the back pieces and
my cutting mat as a guide and just kind of freehand cut them to length to match
the rest of the tavern set I used the same mechanical pencil technique to draw
in all of the little wood grain and knots on these pieces now for the
assembly you just got to glue all the pieces together if you're in a hurry you
can use hot glue for this but it is a little messy for a project this delicate
therefore I prefer to use some sort of PVA glue and in this case I prefer to
use the eileenj tacky glue which is a thicker PVA glue so it will hold and set
up a lot faster and you won't have it sliding around on you quite as much and
for the side pieces you can keep these lengths actually a little extra long and
then that way you don't have to worry about lining things up when you glue it
also it's really helpful to use some little push pins to keep some pressure
on the foam while things dry and the little pin holes will actually add a
nice added detail when it comes to painting
and here I'm just using a wet paint brush to clean up any excess glue that's
squeezing out between the joints I let the glue dry about 15 minutes before
removing the pins and moving on to the next step he used my Olfa knife to cut
the ends flush on one side of these bookcases but I decided I wanted to
leave them a little bit long on the other end so that I could cut in some
little decorative angles then any ends that had a new cut got a quick woodgrain
texture applied with the mechanical pencil and then the most important part
of any foam project is the Mod Podge and black paint coat this will seal your
foam and make it considerably harder and for the first coat of color I made a
kind of medium brown out of some espresso a golden brown and some burnt
umber
after the first coat of brown paint had thoroughly dried I did a liberal dry
brushing with a nice golden brown to start highlighting some of that wood
grain and to complete the paint job I used the same dark brown wash that I
used on the other tavern pieces this gets in all the little nooks and
crannies and really highlights the wood grain and to seal and preserve this
project for many years to come I gave everything a nice liberal coating in
Minwax fast dry polyurethane and there you have it
no excuses no procs on no problem yes some of the things I build on this
